enriched.title: Oswald

enriched.title: Yo Gabba Gabba!
enriched.synopsis: Yo Gabba Gabba! is an American children's television show that airs on the Nick Jr. cable network in the United States and the Nick Jr. networks in the United Kingdom & Ireland, Italy, France and Australia as well as Treehouse TV network in Canada and RTE2 on RTÉjr in Ireland.  The show stars five costumed toys-come-to-life and their friend DJ Lance Rock, who explore a single topic in each episode through songs and short storylines in the half-hour program while teaching children life and social skills.  It also encourages viewers to move along with and dance with the characters in the program. The show is noted for its indie-culture guest stars and bands, and for drawing visual inspiration from 8-bit video games and H. R. Pufnstuff.

assessment.reasoning: This highly energetic preschool program is specifically designed to teach children basic life and social skills, cooperation, and movement through music and bright, whimsical visuals. enriched.title: Curses!

enriched.title: Ice Age: Scrat Tales

enriched.title: Liberty's Kids
enriched.synopsis: Liberty's Kids is an animated educational historical fiction television series produced by DIC Entertainment, originally broadcast on PBS Kids from September 2, 2002 to April 4, 2003, although PBS continued to air reruns until August 2004. The show has since been syndicated by DiC to affiliates of smaller television networks such as The CW and MyNetworkTV and some independent stations so that those stations can fulfill FCC educational and informational requirements. Since September 16, 2006, the series aired on CBS's new block called KOL Secret Slumber Party on CBS, then it was aired on KEWLopolis, which taking September 12, 2009. In 2008 it ran on The History Channel. The series is currently on the Cookie Jar Toons block on This TV and CBS's Cookie Jar TV. In 2012, Qubo announced the channel will air Liberty's Kids in fall 2012. The series was based on an idea by Kevin O'Donnell and developed for television by Kevin O'Donnell, Robby London, Mike Maliani, and Andy Heyward.

assessment.reasoning: The series is an educational historical fiction covering the American Revolution. Because the show involves themes of war, espionage, and battle, it contains moderate historical violence and political conflict, aligning with its TV-Y7 rating.

enriched.title: WordWorld
enriched.synopsis:
WordWorld is an Emmy Award-winning children's television series partially funded by the United States Department of Education as part of the Ready to Learn literacy initiative targeted to 3- to 7-year olds. The show airs in 10 languages and 90 countries, including in the United States. The television series, created by Don Moody and Jacqueline Moody, stars Dog and his WordFriends. In each episode, Dog and/or one of his friends embarks on a series of adventures where the only way to save the day is to build or un-build words. The show's novelty is that when a word is built correctly, it morphs into the thing it represents, which gives instant meaning to the word. WordWorld has been translated into popular mobile applications, Internet-based games, magnetic plush and other toys.

WordWorld currently airs in 90 countries and 10 languages. It premiered September 3, 2007 on PBS Kids and is currently in its third season, with 84 11-minute episodes. WordWorld currently broadcasts on PBS Kids it is produced for WTTW Chicago.

assessment.reasoning: WordWorld is a highly educational, TV-Y rated series specifically designed to promote literacy in children ages 3 to 7, funded by the US Department of Education. The content is gentle, focusing on word construction and problem-solving through language, ensuring a safe and beneficial viewing experience with minimal conflict or frightening elements.

enriched.title: Josie and the Pussycats
enriched.synopsis:
Josie and the Pussycats is an American animated television series, based upon the Archie Comics comic book series of the same name created by Dan DeCarlo. Produced for Saturday morning television by Hanna-Barbera Productions, sixteen episodes of Josie and the Pussycats aired on CBS during the 1970-71 television season, and were rerun during the 1971-72 season. In 1972, the show was re-conceptualized as Josie and the Pussycats in Outer Space, sixteen episodes of which aired on CBS during the 1972-73 season and were rerun the following season. Reruns of the original series alternated between CBS, ABC, and NBC from 1974 through 1976. This brought its national Saturday morning TV run on three networks to six years.

Josie and the Pussycats featured an all-girl pop music band that toured the world with their entourage, getting mixed up in strange adventures, spy capers, and mysteries. On the small-screen, the group consisted of level-headed lead singer and guitarist Josie, intelligent tambourinist Valerie, and air-headed blonde drummer Melody. Other characters included their cowardly manager Alexander Cabot III, his conniving sister Alexandra, her cat Sebastian, and muscular roadie Alan.

assessment.reasoning: This 1970s Hanna-Barbera show is a lighthearted mystery/spy caper focused on music. It features mild, cartoonish violence typical of the era's Saturday morning programming and contains no frightening or mature themes.

enriched.title: Care Bears: Unlock the Magic
enriched.synopsis: A group of lovable, huggable BFFs go on adventures and live that sweet Care Bear life. When a new adventure takes them to a strange new world, the bears have to lean on each other more than ever. Through friendship, courage and a little belly badge magic, the Care Bears continue their mission to spread caring and sharing to the world.

assessment.reasoning: This iteration of Care Bears maintains a strong focus on positive social-emotional lessons, emphasizing friendship, kindness, and courage. Conflicts are mild, resolved non-violently using magical powers, and the content is appropriate and low-risk for the target demographic.

enriched.title: Matt Hatter Chronicles

With his friends Roxie and Gomez, the new Hatter Hero must battle Super Villains, defend the realms, and save his Grandpa!

assessment.reasoning: The show features frequent action and fantasy violence as the hero battles Super Villains across the Multiverse. Its high stimulation level and moderate scary elements (villain designs, suspense) make it better suited for children aged 7 and older.

enriched.title: Maggie and the Ferocious Beast
enriched.synopsis: A precocious 5-year-old named Maggie conjures up an imaginary land where she and her favorite toys, Hamilton Hocks and Ferocious Beast, can play and have adventures. The Ferocious Beast is anything but ferocious, though he is large, with red spots and three horns on his head.
platforms: Amazon Prime Video Free with Ads

assessment.reasoning: This TV-Y rated show is based on gentle imaginary play and friendship, ideal for preschoolers. It features minimal conflict, no scary content (despite the Beast's name), and supports creativity and social-emotional learning.

enriched.title: Jane
enriched.synopsis: Budding environmentalist Jane is a 9-year-old on a quest to save endangered animals. Using her powerful imagination, Jane takes her best friends David and Greybeard the chimpanzee on epic adventures to help protect wild animals all around the world.

assessment.reasoning: The show holds a TV-G certification and focuses on environmental awareness and imagination-fueled adventures, making it exceptionally safe. Content is designed to be gentle, educational, and free of violence or scary imagery. It is highly suitable for preschoolers and early elementary students.

The content is highly gentle, non-violent, and features zero frightening or mature themes, earning a 'Safe' rating for toddlers and young children.

enriched.title: Being Ian
enriched.synopsis:
Being Ian is a Canadian animated series produced by Studio B Productions, Corus Entertainment and Nelvana, focusing on 12-year-old Ian Kelley, who aspires to become a filmmaker. It originally aired from January 1, 2005 to April 22, 2007.

The series is created by and based on the early life of actor/writer Ian James Corlett. It is set in the city of Burnaby, British Columbia. Produced in 2004, it debuted January 4, 2005 on YTV. The series aired in the United States on Qubo from September 19, 2009 - October 24, 2009.
platforms: Amazon Prime Video Free with Ads

assessment.reasoning: The series is a standard TV-Y7 animated family comedy focusing on the exaggerated misadventures of a creative young boy. Content includes frequent cartoonish slapstick violence and situational conflicts typical of the genre, but lacks intense scary or mature themes. It is considered safe for school-aged children and promotes themes of creativity and family values.

enriched.title: Henry Hugglemonster
enriched.synopsis: Henry Hugglemonster is the story of a mischievous 5-year-old monster named Henry who loves adventures, discoveries, and being with his family. Each day brings new opportunities for Henry to explore his feelings and learn important life lessons about working with others, showing kindness, and getting along with siblings. Henry finds love and support from his parents, Daddo and Momma; and his brothers and sisters, Cobby , Summer, and Ivor.

assessment.reasoning: This TV-Y rated series is highly suitable for toddlers and preschoolers, focusing primarily on social-emotional learning, cooperation, and kindness. The 'hugglemonster' theme is gentle and non-frightening, and the show features no violence or intense scary imagery. The content is educational, teaching children important life lessons about navigating family dynamics and social interactions.

enriched.title: KaBlam!
enriched.synopsis: KaBlam! is a sketch comedy television series that ran from 1996 to 2000. It features a collection of short films in several different styles of animation, bridged by the characters of Henry and June, who introduce the shorts, and have adventures of their own. The show ended its three-year run nine months short of four years on January 22, 2000.

assessment.reasoning: KaBlam! is a high-energy sketch show featuring various forms of animation and rapid pacing. While non-serious, many segments (like 'Action League Now!') contain frequent stylized slapstick and cartoon violence. It is best suited for children aged 6 and up due to the high stimulation and abstract comedic elements.

enriched.title: Spirit Riding Free: Riding Academy

enriched.title: Alf Tales
enriched.synopsis:
ALF Tales is an animated American series that ran on the NBC television network on Saturdays from August 1988 to December 1989. The show was a spinoff from the series ALF: The Animated Series. The show had characters from that series play various characters from fairy tales. The fairy tale was usually altered for comedic effect in a manner relational to Fractured Fairy Tales.

Each story typically spoofs a film genre, such as the "Cinderella" episode done as an Elvis movie. Some episodes featured a "fourth wall" effect where ALF is backstage preparing for the episode, and Rob Cowan would appear drawn as a TV executive to try to brief ALF on how to improve this episode. For instance Cowan once told ALF who was readying for a medieval themed episode that "less than 2% of our audience lives in the Dark Ages".
platforms: Amazon Prime Video Free with Ads

assessment.reasoning: Alf Tales is a comedic animated series featuring parodies of classic fairy tales. The show's focus on meta-humor and slapstick keeps the tone light and is appropriate for children aged 4 and up who can follow comedic narrative changes. Any mild conflict present is highly mitigated by humor and is non-threatening.

enriched.title: The Koala Brothers
enriched.synopsis: The Koala Brothers, Frank and Buster, live in the Australian Outback, where their mission in life is to help their friends.

assessment.reasoning: This show is extremely gentle, focusing entirely on pro-social themes like helping others and friendship. Rated TV-Y, it contains no violence, scary elements, or complex themes, making it very safe for young preschoolers.

enriched.title: Horseland
enriched.synopsis: Horseland is an American animated series produced by DIC Entertainment. It is a comic mischief program following events in the lives of a group of children riding at Horseland, an equestrian school and stables. Their adventures include riding, and raising and entering their horses in competitions. The show premiered on September 16, 2006 as part of CBS's new Saturday morning cartoon block, KOL Secret Slumber Party on CBS. Concurrent with the series, the online virtual pet game that it was based upon was updated to complement the show by launching a new "Junior version" of the game based on the program and featuring its various characters and locations. After three seasons, the show's original run ended on CBS on September 19, 2009.

assessment.reasoning: Horseland is a 'Safe' family animation focusing on equestrian life, friendship, and positive competition. The content is suitable for school-aged children, featuring only comic mischief and minor character rivalries, with no concerning levels of violence or scary imagery. The show promotes positive themes such as responsibility, animal care, and teamwork.

enriched.title: Zootopia 2

enriched.title: Hitpig!

assessment.reasoning: This film receives a 'Caution' rating due to the PG certification and core themes involving a bounty hunter and a 'hit,' implying moderate action and chase sequences. enriched.title: Tangled
enriched.synopsis: Feisty teenager Rapunzel, who has long and magical hair, wants to go and see sky lanterns on her eighteenth birthday, but she's bound to a tower by her overprotective mother. assessment.reasoning: This movie receives a Caution rating due to moderate action violence (chases, fighting, peril) and the presence of a psychologically manipulative villain whose actions and eventual demise may be frightening for very young viewers. enriched.title: Inside Out 2

Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust, who’ve long been running a successful operation by all accounts, aren’t sure how to feel when Anxiety shows up. And it looks like she’s not alone.

assessment.reasoning: The film deals with complex, high-stakes psychological themes like severe anxiety, identity crisis, and panic attacks, which may be too intense or abstract for younger children. enriched.title: Shrek

assessment.reasoning: Shrek is rated PG due to moderate fantasy violence (dragon encounters, fights with guards) and some rude humor. The high stimulation and frightening imagery may be overwhelming for children under seven, warranting a 'Caution' rating, though the film promotes positive values.

enriched.title: Frozen
